title: Elidir Fawr Walk Route

images.title: Eric Jones / The summit ridge of Elidir Fawr
images.caption: A dog poses on the summit ridge of Elidir Fawr. The rocky summit ridge of the mountain is capped by a cairn which has been adapted into a wind shelter.

images.title: dave roberts / Marchlyn Mawr from Elidir Fawr
images.caption: Marchlyn Mawr from Elidir Fawr. Showing the Lake present in that square, and the scree slopes to the foreground. The Dam is in another square.

images.title: Eric Jones / Elidir Fawr - the Summit Cairn and Shelter
images.caption: The Summit Cairn and Shelter. The highest point on Elidir Fawr [924m] is marked by a small cairn. A short distance east is a stone shelter. The mountains in the background are the Carneddau. Foel Goch intrudes into the picture [middleground, right].

images.title: Eric Jones / Looking towards the summit of Elidir Fawr
images.caption: Looking towards the summit

images.title: Eric Jones / The Bwlch Melynwyn Gap on the summit ridge of Elidir Fawr
images.caption: The Bwlch Melynwyn Gap on the summit ridge of Elidir Fawr. Y Tryfan and Glyder Fawr can be seen in the background.

images.title: Eric Jones / Marchlyn Mawr Reservoir and the East Face of Elidir Fawr
images.caption: Marchlyn Mawr Reservoir and the East Face.

description: Climb to Elidir Fawr, the northernmost peak in the Glyderau range on this challenging walk in Snowdonia. The walk takes you to the 924 metre (3,031 ft) summit from the village of Nant Peris at the bottom of the Llanberis Pass. It's only about a 2 mile climb, but quite steep. The walk starts from the parking areas off the A4086 in Nant Peris. Cross the A4086 and then pick up a country lane heading north. A footpath then takes you the rest of the way to the summit, passing the Afon Dudodyn on the way. There are fabulous views over the peaks and reservoirs of the national park. You can extend the walk by continuing a short way on to the pretty Marchlyn Mawr reservoir. Following the path further will take you to Foel-Goch and then on to Y Garn . From the 947 m (3,107 ft) summit there are great views of Llyn Clyd and the Ogwen Valley. Also nearby are the climbs to Glyder Fawr and Glyder Fach and Tryfan .
